This wouldnt impact the course of removing malaria however as both types of mosquitoes would benefit to a dwindling malaria selection until it fades into nothing, but they do benefit at face value.

If we do use the technology, estimate 3.5 billion will die.
So we don't use the technology

What do I think? In an oversimplified thinking, Malaria and many other disease keep overpopulation in check.

More complicated answer : Although, industrialized countries has a reproduction rate of 2.1, Third world countries has 2.3 due to high mortality rate. While current industrialized countries progressed "slowly" towards a "low" reproduction rate that isn't due to high mortality rate and cost of living is also influencing decision to have children, I'm not sure we can assume that it would be stable in developing countries if there was a sudden and rapid drop in mortality rate.

In comparison, you can see how introduction of industrialized world technologies (mostly vehicles and weapons) has somewhat catastrophically changed some countries. Constant wars and terrible roadworks. China hoped on the chance to loanshark a country because that country wanted to rapidly upgrade their infrastructures. Unable to repay, China now owns large portion of it. We constantly hear about unfair wages in those countries, but their living cost is still far under ours. If wages were to rapidly grow, so would cost of living. I'm not saying it shouldn't be done, but should be done progressively not disrupt balance for worst.

Every choice we make is never for the long term of humanity. If it were then so many things would be torn down. Broken voting systems, that once worked when countries were expecting only 100k people, would get uprooted. Global warming would be stopped, and so would petty squabbles, wars, and starvation. We have the things needed to stop or at least slow these but decide not to because it would be more beneficial to the few. Most of our current policies and decisions are to bring about benefits in the insane short term, of 1-50 years. That might seem long but compared to the length of time humanity has existed, that's hardly a blink. We simply don't think about things far enough ahead, and simply put it off as "well if that's a problem later, we'll deal with it". The entire history of humanity is that of "time to make a decision to fix the present", which forces new consequences onto future generations, intended or not. Suddenly stepping back and being like "well this can have negative consequences in the future so let's not act" is just so tone-deaf to me. If we have the power to act, then lets do so. Of course look it over, such that a negative reaction is less likely, but ultimately saving more people is always beneficial. Especially since it will help alot for the groundwork of modernization for alot of 3rd world countries, which boosts quality of life, and education by alot. In the end if it does go sour, then more people, who are able to live long enough and get an education, means more minds contributing to solving an issue. In the end, making a choice, that might have unpredictable consequences for the future, is the most human thing we can do.

Only two kinds of people get to Heaven: perfect people, and forgiven sinners.

What is perfect? Well, not stealing regardless of how insignificant it may seem, not saying a single evil word against anyone - not to mention God sees our thought life. And like a judge in court, a penalty has to be paid when evil is done and laws are broken (e.g. if a murderer was let off in court there would be uproar so how much more God)?

In short - we arent perfect, at all. And rather than Heaven, God, if giving us justice, will have to make us pay for our crimes by death and eternal damnation in an everlasting fire and torment. THAT’s how much God hates sin.

BUT:
There is a way that we can be saved. AND completely forgiven. Jesus - the Son of God - came down to live a perfect life without sin, conquering all evil and the devil's sinful, lustful traps that so easily ensnare us. Jesus overcame all of that, and was then sentenced to death on a cross.

While on the cross, God poured out the anger and wrath of sin on His Son - Jesus took OUR fine of damnation in our place. That’s how much He loves us. Unbearable pain and being separated from God. EVERY single evil thought, word or deed that doesnt line up with God' perfection, every sin you ever have/will commit knowingly or unknowingly, Jesus took the complete, undiluted wrath for.

GOD HAS VICTORY OVER DEATH.

This is your chance now.

It’s not only about escaping damnation, it’s entering God’s healing as well. God has a plan for your life, a plan that involves you being recreated into His perfect moral image AGAIN as we were before the sin in the garden. He loves you and wants to cleanse you - He will give you the strength. Now we can walk in His strength, experiencing His love, being taught what it means to be part of His family and too be given victory over sin and death.

The story of Malaria has become a story of First World arrogance. The U.S. CDC was originally founded in order to fight malaria in the U.S. Malaria used to be present in many more places than it currently is. How did we eradicate malaria from the 1st world? We used DDT. DDT is the "controversial" chemical talked about in Silent Spring. If you've ever read some of Silent Spring, you'll know how reactionary, emotional, and unscientific it is, yet it scared everyone out of using DDT, a convenient and easy choice to show our virtues after DDT had already eradicated malaria in the places people cared about.

There's no real evidence to show it was a health risk to humans (baby boomers, who grew up at the height of DDT usage are living long enough to be a strain on the medical sector), and after decades of DDT spraying, the damage to the ecosystem was so minimal that it was ultimately recoverable in a few years. What about Africa? the jungles of South America? oh well, we said you can't use DDT because it is bad. Easy for us to say when we don't have millions of people dying from malaria. Finally, after years and years, people are coming back around to it. India said, "screw you guys," and domestically produces DDT. It is used in Africa and other places as well, but to a much lesser extent (DDT paint, other DDT infused product) than it was in the days where DDT trucks sprayed clouds into city streets.

jokes aside:
Malaria is a horrible disease, but it's probably been here longer than us. although all parasites are disgusting in their own right they do help keep the population in check.
it's like us wiping out the wolf population just because they eat a few cattle every year. If we do exterminate them then there would be no other preditors to keep the prey population in check and pretty soon the prey would overgraze and render the ecosystem in shambles.


humans alone cannot keep vast populations of fish or deer in check on their own it's even a challenge for preditors to do so, this is where parasites and diseases come in. they help keep the overall population in check by weeding out weak organisms that have a low chance of survival and at the same time, they make strong healthy species by having them adapt and overcome keeping genetic diversity alive and by extension the populace.
so instead of changing the environment, we should change ourselves. we have to adapt and develop immunization towards malaria and other illnesses so that the overall population stays strong and that we don't subsequently fuck up nature to a point of no return.

Apparently this vid exploded earlier this year. Ended up doing a project on CRISPR 2 years back, but my understanding of the approach to this at the time was to create mosquitoes that couldn't breed. My particular project ended up focusing on trying to remove invasive species entirely by introducing mutations that makes males more attractive and infertile while females remained fertile with gene drive. It seemed relatively sound besides having to change legislation around capture to facilitate spreading it.


One thing I stumbled on while doing research was that it's extremely problematic for a gene drive to fail; it behaves much like surviving an infection, and it becomes extremely difficult to spread the drive to that organism or even its offspring. On the other hand, changing multiple genes for the purpose of driving one trait (I think the term was multiplexing) lets the success rate go much higher, to the tune of a 13-14-fold version could reasonably spread through the entirety of Africa's mosquito population without failing.


I should look this stuff up again, though.

to those wondering if bacteriophages could work against malaria:


malaria is caused by plasmodium, which is a species of protozoa (eukaryotic parasitic cells). Bacteriophages can only infect and kill...well bacteria, which are prokaryotes. So sadly bacteriophages will just ignore plasmodium.

This may sound cold, but we really are not at the right point as a species yet to be messing with things like this. Here’s the cold part, death is an essential part of nature. As are all of the natural forms it comes in. Especially disease. I’m not saying that it’s good so many people die from malaria. But if we are going to put such a large amount of research into saving lives, we need to put an equal or greater amount of research towards new habitats for us as well. Like mars, or the moon, or even just plain old space. Earth can only support so much, it only has so many resources, and we can’t keep messing with its mechanisms of maintaining the environment. Unless we are going to also provide support for our niche. Earth is like a brewing carboy. You add yeast and watch it ferment the sugar into alcohol as a waste product. But eventually the yeast will produce so much alcohol that it kills it’s entire population in the carboy. We are the yeast in this case. Don’t get me wrong, It’s great that we are saving so many lives. In fact, without modern medicine I would have died from strep B as a baby.. but we need to make sure we also have places for all of the lives we are saving. Otherwise it’s counterproductive, maybe even cruel. Because you are saving lives just so they may eventually die from the horrifying results of overpopulation. So to anybody who opposes us colonizing other planets, you should also be opposing medical advancement. Because they 100% go hand in hand. By all means, exterminate malaria. But let’s build some freaking awesome moon colonies and mars colonies too. So we can keep on growing, keep on learning, and keep on being amazing. And at the same time, not being forced to destroy other life on earth just so we can sustain ourselves.. because that will end badly for everyone. Especially us.

I have been wanting to explore with this topic by writing a book. A book that takes place in a world where some people have been genetically modified, cloned, and even created.

My thoughts right now are to present both sides with valid arguments. The biggest question here is: is it humane?

I personally think it is time to evolve humans in the ways that transcend nature itself. I believe it is time to experiment gene splicing for humans.

The potentials for this technology would be endless. A hypothetical example I have thought of would be mixing a particular gene from crocodilians into humans. Crocodilians have the most advanced immune systems in the animal kingdom, able to repel and become immune to virtually any disease know to man thanks to their blood.

I know I sound like Dr. Curtis Conners, but it is a valid reason to invest in this technology! Humans could inherit the most valuable parts of animals and evolve faster than nature would allow!

But that question is the drawback. Is it humane?

If we would create and alter humans in such a way, would it be our responsibility if this technology that was created to solve problems fell into the wrong hands? If we modified and experimented on a human embryo, would it be right for us to do so?

African here and my view is the disease burden of malaria is so significant and can never be overestimated in endemic regions and as someone who has lived in such areas I know first hand what it can do; it stunts the development of children and so much money is lost yearly due to people taking sick days off from their work since on average people will contract malaria 2 to 3 times in the year.Its so significant that 99 percent of black africans have a mutation offering resistance to malaria vivax, another one changes the structure of hemoglobin turning cells into the sickle shape (another deadly condition if you end up being homozygous for the mutation).Based on the condition of the individual/family, malaria is not a big deal anymore because the drug to treat it costs about 1 dollar but I remember when I told my friends abroad I have had malaria they looked at me in shock and asked how I survived, so the burden is really in poorer regions,I think they will benefit from this method in the long run,besides it will definitely be cheaper than attempting eradication by other means.Perhaps feasibility studies can be done assessing the niche mosquitoes fill and how not carrying plasmodium may affect the whole ecosystem, will plasmodium mutate and find a different host I think highly unlikely.Will the editing of that particular gene result in changes in their life cycle, maturation, behavior etc.

Here in Brazil we use genetic engineering mosquitoes in institutions like Friocruz in Rio.

We release them in the city: mosquitoes with shining colours and we distribute a lot of flyers that indicates that this kind of mosquitoes should not be killed by the population. But there's no plasmodium antibody, only a bacteria called Wolbachia. With Wolbachia, the mosquitoes increase their resistance agaisnt Zika virus, dengue and other diseases that affects Brazil. Then the researchers collect mosquitoes in the wild and with genetic engineering they know exactly the porcentage of wolbachia mosquitoes (we call allies mosquitoes) and normal mosquitos in the wild present in the population of determinated area. So they can release more allies mosquitoes and them reduce this type of diseases in big cities like Rio.

Para meus colegas brasileiros, uma frase de um grande pesquisador da fiocruz sobre esse tema:
“Existe um esforço mundial para implantar o método que utiliza o Aedes aegypti com Wolbachia no combate à transmissão de arboviroses. Participamos desse esforço e nosso objetivo é ter êxito na substituição da população de mosquitos de campo por estes mosquitos que têm a capacidade reduzida de transmitir doenças”
-Luciano Moreira.

I'd like to submit a valid but morbid concern.. I'm all for saving lives, but executing this would mean that we have another 500K people per year surviving. That's about 40% of my home city every year. What effect will this have on the economies, food supplies, and climate, and how can we prepare for this change ahead of time?
I'm not suggesting that we never implement it, just that we take a bit of time beforehand to examine what effects this will have. half a million is not a small number, and this means slightly accelerated population growth worldwide, unless the birth rate decreases to compensate for the survival rate. Absolutely yes. It should be prepared so that it can be rapidly rolled out, such that once it begins, there is little to no time for the disease to adapt.
However, in the broader scale of the gene drive, it is an extremely powerful weapon that needs to be treated with the respect it deserves. For example, many rodents are known for bringing pestilence and ruining food supply, but also for being an important part of the food chain. Extincting them would be a horrible idea.
If no way to make a mosquito species not carry a parasite can be found, then eliminating that species is not really too much of an issue in my book. The ecological niche can most likely be filled by the many less destructive species of mosquito, and some of mosquitos' current population could be an effect of humans anyway, meaning the problems caused may be something we could solve by changing how we interact with the environment (somehow replacing the human-derived food source that the mosquitos were feeding to predators, with something else, perhaps better handling of waste).
There are many species that are being destroyed by humans' greedy actions, destroying a few of the many varieties of mosquito is much smaller and more important than that. If we can both spay the bird-eating cats(though we need a replacement rodent solution, maybe some of the birds themselves?) and gene-spay the dangerous varieties of mosquito, that would be net important-gene-saving progress in my book, in addition to the massive ecological and humanitarian benefits.
The needs of humanity and the needs of the fragile and not-fully-understood needs of the environment, required to sustain humanity's needs, must be carefully balanced.

Maybe, we could do something to the genes of mosquitos that not only makes them immune to plasmoiduiums  but also kill them in a way they could never adapt. We need to investigate the ways that malaria mutates and adapts to change so that we can prepare for it. For instance, we could track down their origin before mosquitos and observe how malaria parasites adapt and thrive in their environment and find out how to counter it. This may be difficult considering the fact that millions to trillions of viruses exist, some we haven't even discovered yet and we only eradicated one virus, small pox. My idea is thst maybe instead of modifying mosquitos, we could either modify ourselves or genetically engineer the virus in a way that it could make itself harmless and extinct. Maybe,  if we master the effects of manual genetic modification on humans, we could modify ourselves to have an immunity to malaria and possibly other diseases.  We could also just try to increase the amount of species that could  change the habitable climate for plasmodium.

The real question is population growth. Nature is one of the things that "slows" population growth. Now that we are at the top of the food chain and realistically have no natural predators to keep us in check our population has skyrocketed to the point that we do not have the resources to supply it. So having something like malaria or H1N1 actually kind of helps us.
i want 2 use it

If we can genetically program mosquitoes so they don't want to bite humans (and preferably so they don't want to bite our pets either) or program them so their immune systems will kill off malaria then that would be preferably to programming them into extinction.

But if we can't do those things then by all means wipe out the mosquitoes! Human lives > Mosquito lives. As for ecology, name one animal that lives solely off of mosquitoes. Flies and other insects will quickly fill in the niche left behind. If there are ecosystems where adjusting to this would be particularly difficult then we should simultaneously encourage the repopulation of those areas with replacement prey through breeding and releasing captive colonies of the replacement species.

We should also consider wiping out ticks. They are only good for spreading lyme disease. EDIT: Someone will bring up that they are food for many species of spiders. The solution should be to encourage substitute prey species, not to conserve a species of insect responsible for spreading an often lethal infection to humans.

Considering the ecological impact is important. But too often people say "it would have this effect on the ecosystem, so we just shouldn't do it" without considering that additional interventions could reduce or eliminate the negative side effects. Of course the impact of those interventions also has to be considered, but in many cases there could be a solution which would do very little damage, not risking any unwanted extinctions, and maybe even improving some aspects of our environment or climate.

This problem is in many ways alike to artifitial inteligence problem meaning you either get it perfectly right at the start or we will all get screwed in a way we can't possibly imagine. Once the modified mosqitoes are out we have billions of oportunities for some random unfortunate mutation to backfire. And you cannot really "patch" the problem at that point as any further modification is only increasing the complexity of situation thus making more opportunities for bad mutations.
With as big population as mosqitoes you really cannot take any chances as the probability of some terrible outcome is quite severe.

I think this approach should be taken only if we are certain we cannot solve the problem in any other way.
If we decide we are at that point we need to be extremely diligent about testing the potential solutions. We would need to have nearly full knowledge on possible outcomes before taking a decision to release. Quite frankly i don't think we are even close to being there

Huh - the pre-CRISPR version I'd heard of for solving the Malaria problem was engineering a smaller mosquito that had a proboscis that was physically too small for the malaria parasite. The issues there were "how do we replace the old mosquitoes with our minimosquitoes?" and "what will shrinking mosquito sizes do to all of the things higher up in the food web that rely on mosquito protein in some form?"

Personally, I would suggest there be one test to be done before making a final launch decision, and frankly I'd say this test should always be done with any genetically engineered sample: Put it in an enclosed environment and see what happens.

Build a large box. Put some small scale grazer in for the mosquitoes to bite, and whatever food those and the mosquitoes need. Release a bunch of unaltered mosquitoes into the box along with a few of the genetically engineered variety - wait a few generations, then introduce malaria to the environment. See if the grazers get sick. (Possibly introduce malaria right at the start, but that's dependent on whether whatever mammal you selected to be the bite victim (I said "grazers" because you want it to be a plant eater - saves you from potentially compromising the seal by having to do daily feedings). If it only survives malaria in the wild by being widespread enough that not all of the population is dying from malaria at the same time, then you can't have malaria in the system at the start.)

Somewhat of a crude idea, but it's the best small scale mockup of the scenario I can think of. Perhaps the scientists studying it can come up with a better system?

Anyway, the result of the test is either "the new gene worked as intended," "the new gene had no effect," or "the new gene did something unexpected and we're very glad we didn't release that into nature." If it works, go for it. If it doesn't work, go back to the drawing board. If something goes horribly sideways, maybe you don't understand your new tools as much as you think you do.

I think the risks outweigh the benefits in this case. The interactions of releasing such a modified organism into the wild are unknown and unknowable; it could never be a controlled experiment. The web of life has interactions upon interactions that we can't even begin to comprehend. Modifying mosquitoes could have huge unintended consequences. I'm all for CRISPR, and making genetic modifications to humans who have signed off on the risks is one thing, but recklessly attempting to modify organisms in the wild could be hugely disruptive to a balance that has already become threatened by climate change and other forces, such as ocean acidification and the spectre of global biotic homogenization.

There are other, more conventional ways to combat malaria and other diseases which we haven't even tried. When was the last time you heard an American politician speak of increasing foreign aid? Building treatment centers and educating the public is the key to beating disease in developing nations, not radical untested field experiments in genetic modification.

In the case of altering biology to cause permanent change to entire species we have to be as sure as possible that our edits will not themselves be edited or at least not easily edited themselves by natural evolution. In other words, our genetic edits may come with an upkeep cost of having to re-introduce our edits or worse, fight a naturally occurring "edit" (natrual evolution of the same variety that we introduce artificially) that increases the cost or worse than all of that is more effective than our changes. It is reasonable to accept this more than you might think. Genetic changes to happen as a result of evolution (breeding) but also happen based on mutation (non breeding reasons that cannot be controlled). It is the 2nd reason that we should be careful because the edits do not exist yet to be altered by mutation but breeding will exist in either event meaning that any changes and mutations of those changes will spread. End result: Let us learn more first so we can ENSURE the suffering not only diminishes but actually stays diminished or even can be removed forever (polio cough cough (*see what I did there?) ).

Yet another video which downplays the VERY valid concerns about CRISPR technology and how the vectors used can easily mutate other bits of genetic code in unforeseen and even presently undetectable ways. There is a reason why almost all people who undergo gene editing for leukemia (this is an actual treatment) end up developing another type of cancer.

A very simple example of how this could go terribly wrong (and this isn't even due to CRISPR) is malaria would adapt to the antibody and gain resistance, depriving us of that particular antibody/method to treat malaria. What happens when you release this into the wild, the plasmodium adapt, and we can no longer treat malaria with atovaquone or doxycycline?

Better yet, what if this genetic edit causes defects in the offspring/egg production of mosquitoes down the road (as CRISPR has been demonstrably shown to do)? The knock-on effects of depopulating the mosquito could be cataclysmic for many species who rely on them.

We would be gambling the lives of 500,000 people anually with the lives of 199,500,000 people anually.

Why should we not use CRISPR and genetically modify mosquitos? Because we can develop vaccines, because vaccines are well understood, and we won't unleash/cause potentially problematic effects/changes in our environment by using them.

CRISPR and synthetic biology is a field worthy of research, but it holds to answer for a select group of problems and we shouldn't dare to employ it on such a large scale without a perfect and thorough understanding of the technology. We have better options available to use, and they're called healthcare, education, and vaccination.

This is the second time you've brought up CRISPR without adequately addressing the very real concerns about the technology, and much like almost every other science communicator you are contributing to a highly optimistic (and not realistic) view of science.
WHAT IF the plasmodium was able to adapt to the antibodies, what possible solution can be done to stop it?

If it wasn't done already, scientists may want to TRY to cause a negative mutation using materials that the mosquitoes may encounter in the world. They will also want to test it to its limit by breeding multiple generations of these from a very small host with a large host of "wild" mosquitoes and using the offspring to produce the next generation. Effectively, a stress test of the altered genes. Can't forget to test the mosquitoes for chemical resistance and thermal tolerance. Really don't need mosquitoes that can fly around in freezing weather. Lastly, hit the new ones with a slew of various blood-bourne diseases and parasites to see if they are altered. The new anti-body may prevent malaria but it may also allow a new pathogen to be carried.

TLDR: TEST EVERYTHING FIRST!

Just a thought: since we are working on CRISPR technology, why shouldn't we make sure that we are immune / that we develop a vaccine against diseases x,y and z for our own genetic code? Instead of meddling with the genetic structure of a different species, we might want to ensure that we are able to protect our own without to much interference within the natural evolution of a ecosystem that we barley understand.

Not to be an pessimist or anything, but i honestly think we need to solve the problem of human overpopulation on earth before considering eradicating natural population control methods that nature has created. Malaria, unfortunately, i have to say is one of them. Until humans can find a second planet/big moon to populate, or until we can learn enough self control to "keep it in our pants" so to say.... I think CRISPER will be our own undoing should we decide to use it, before we can even handle the population consequence. A perfect example to prove that this is an actual concern is the Refugee crisis that we are currently going through. So many people have been displaced, but they are finding fewer and fewer places to go to because, well, some countries are already at their limit with trying to care for the current populations that they hold.

To play Devil's advocate here: Sure, we end malaria, then the human population in areas where malaria existed explode (typically those areas are 3rd world and low income) which causes even more hunger and death because we solved one problem and exacerbated another. The risks aren't just genetic engineering, there are more wide reaching possible effects as well. - NOTE: I am not arguing against or for, but just think about other non-direct effects of this change.

This strongly depends on the type of antibodies we're causing these new mosquitos to synthesize.

If they are the same type that humans use against it, and it adapts to avoid these antibodies, the human casualty results would be more catastrophic than the Black Plague ever could have been. We would have created a super-bug far more potent than any misuse of antibiotics could, and much more concerning than MRSA/VRSA, Brucella spp, HBV, CMV, S. pyogenes, B. anthracis, Ebola, and F. tularensis COMBINED.

However, if the antibodies being used are something different enough from the human version, then the worst risk is simply failure to work.

Hmmm, I lived in The Gambia West Africa for fifteen years, I had Malaria eight times while I lived there and once a few years later back in England. The first time it almost killed me, I spent 2 weeks on a drip in a medical research centre and I saw ten people on my ward die from it. I honestly thought I was next, but after you have it once it never goes away and you just get used to it, you learn to know your symptoms and take the appropriate medication when you feel it coming . You can put it to sleep again but it just lays dormant inside you until a small infection wakes it up again. I have seen seven other people I know die from Malaria & Cerebral Malaria and each time it was quicker than the last. Malaria changes all the time and every country has its own strain, as much as I would love to see this virus eradicated I cannot see it happening. As for the whole changing DNA structure of any living thing I cannot see that ever being a safe option, the moment you Change something you open the door for even more change, evolution is a very powerful thing in it's won right and then you want to give it the power to make rapid changes? Is it unethical to remove a natural predator from the world? Think about it like this ecosystems are complex and diverse, with many levels and intricate relationships between organisms. Removing any level from an ecosystem disrupts a delicate balance that may have evolved over millions of years. These systems are compromised of a series of checks and balances between predator and prey, that tend to balance the whole. The several impacts, some of which are expected, and others surprising. Population explosions the most obvious result of the removal of top predators in an ecosystem is a population explosion in the prey species. When taking action of such a scale you have to way in the actual cause and effect of these actions. Trophies cascade or a chain of events could lead to other problems with the eradication of the mosquito bacteria carrying population. Without any predators to limit population growth, humans in this case reproduce without a check, and all of them hungry. More humans eating and without anything to control them, they can quickly degrade their habitat. This puts pressure on our food that we depend on, sometimes to the point of impeding plant reproduction and defoliation habitat. To put it in simpler terms the removal of malaria or any other form of predator could in turn leave prey unchecked in this case humans meaning more humans those millions that would die would be alive and they would have to eat and use resources which could in turn lead to the catastrophic extinction of another species. Although it may seem cruel to not save human lives with any chance we get think about what could happen when we take these measures. We could in turn increase our own impending demise as our population increases so does the strain and competition for food and space. This could further cause unforeseen problems in the environment. It may be a quick fix that may lead to a bigger problem in the future.

Given how it was described in this video it seems the risks are low. However we should get our practice at fail safes now because we'll certainly need them later. It makes far more sense to keep the gene recessive and test it in isolated areas.

This is one of the hardest ethical questions going forward with ethics and technology... not so much the CRISPR part but the gene drive... pushing forth dominant gene inheritances. I mean its in a way violating the most basic of natural selection / gene inheritance laws. Kurz says it himself that gene inheritance being dominant / recessive is a failsafe, if a negative gene is developed / inherited it only statistically affects a sample of the next gen. Conversely if it is favourable mutation then it passes on etc. Evolution by nature is diversity, chaos and multiplicity. The gene drive potentially has the ability to destroy the genetic diversity here... which is worrying. What happens if this force genetic inheritance has some unpredictable response? What happens if in populations of mosquitoes without the malaria plasmodes that the antibodies attack the host much like an allergic reaction??? Or something to that affect? There would be no "failsafe" from the deadly inherited gene, there would be no safe sample group to survive through. I mean this is all hypothetical... and I'm not arguing agains CRISPR or Gene drives. But I guess this is the ethical dilemma at hand.... will the short term benefits be justified by long-term stability? Will this ruin or forever taint genetic diversity in these populations?

Should we do it? That's a tough question.

On the ONE hand...

Stopping Malaria would be an achievement that would dwarf our current disease eradication success story - Smallpox - with ease. And expanding the tech to other diseases by making their carriers hostile to the diseases they carry could well lead to a new Renaissance in parts of the world that are frequently held back developmentally because of rampant disease. (Humans in Africa, for example, could benefit tremendously from not having to deal with some of their more endemic diseases.)

On the OTHER hand...

Humanity seems to have a collective blind spot regarding the Law of Unintended Consequences, and the unintended consequences to editing the genomes of living things are completely unknown to us at present. We could end up creating "superbugs," of both "insect" and "disease" senses of the word "bug," and could greatly exacerbate the problems caused by the very diseases being targeted.

So, should we do it? I don't think there's a clear answer to that, at least not now.

I would be all for stopping this virus, if the human population wasn't growing so fast, or we had easy transportation to other hospitable planets. By saving the lives of so many, we will also be bringing the end of our race sooner, unless something else ends the race before overpopulation and lack of food. But this, as well as many other "better Earth" opportunities, is a huge moral issue of sacrificing some to save many more.

I think that although there are risks, they are rather minimal in comparison to what we can do with this. For one, it doesn't heavily affect the mosquito's genome, and for another, there's little risk of creating a superbug. Even if malaria adapts to the change, we can just change something else to make our defenses more effective.

Malaria has been a around for a really long time now.  In fact, there was a time when Europe and the U.S. were heavily populated with malaria victims.  Yet, we were able to eradicate it in due time.  In our day, African countries, specifically poor African countries, suffer from malaria and have been suffering from malaria.  So, why is it that this is the case?  Malaria is not only an ethical issue or medical issue.  It's a HUGE global issue that encompasses ethics, science, economics, poverty, and culture.  Yes, we can focus on genetically altering mosquitos to abolish malaria, but we can do more if we tackle the whole entire issue that is MALARIA.  For more information, check out the TED talk by Sonia Shah.

The mechanism of forcing inheritance is the most dangerous part. We are adding DNA that would force-replicate itself throughout a population, and DNA can be spread to other organisms. It could be risking the creation of a new kind of virus.

Hands up for anyone who knew that CRISPR was first discovered in the 80s, but CRISPR/CAS9 is more recent? Honestly, this is a valid discussion. There are pros and cons to this. In some respect we should take the emotional argument out of it, but in other valid reasons we shouldn't. This is certainly a grey area. I am personally of the fuck it lets go camp, but I'm also an immunologist so I may have a jaded view of disease. I'm thinking vaccination will likely come first, but I digress.

Also this may be nitpicking but technically the mosquitoes don't have antibodies. What was done was adding on antigenic binding regions of antibodies onto antimicrobial peptides present in mosquitoes. This could potentially have "wide" implications, but overall it is unlikely to overly effect them. I'm assuming there are likely numerous copies of these antimicrobial peptides for redundancy, and even if resistance to the antibodies are garnered, it is unlikely to make Malaria "worse".

Malaria is a horrible disease. In fact, it's the most horrible disease in all of human history. If a gene drive is used to try and eradicate it, and it not only fails but makes malaria even more horrible, malaria will become the most horrible disease in all of human history. Which it already is.

A gene drive intended to target malaria by hard-coding production of certain antibodies might possibly put that species of mosquito at a significant evolutionary disadvantage, causing their extinction and some mild upheaval in the local ecosystem. Then a different species of mosquito or other insect, most of which are not able to carry malaria, would take over the ecological niche, millions of lives would be saved, and the world would keep on turning.

Last possibility: the gene drive works exactly as intended, and fast enough that malaria fails to adapt, and millions of lives have been saved. I'd have to say the benefits outweigh the potential risks.

More to the point, a full-scale attempt at editing the genome of an entire species under careful observation has to happen within a few years, or some graduate student somewhere will make their own gene drive, release it into the wild because they know it'll work, and kill hundreds of millions of humans. Say, because their best friend was killed by an allergic reaction to a bee-sting, and a recessive infertility gene is easier to make than editing the chemical composition of apitoxin, through DNA, to not cause allergic reactions in any humans what-so-ever (or rather replace the coding for apitoxin with the coding for something else that no humans are allergic to, which the bees can use just as effectively to defend themselves and their colony).

Hopefully no one smart enough to cause infertility in bees will be naive enough to think it's a good idea, but CRISPR is powerful enough that it's really only a matter of time before something terrible is done with it, and I'd rather it happen under closely monitored conditions and for a very good reason, so that we have the best possible chance of fixing whatever happened before it kills millions of people.

I can think of worse ways to use this technology. But do we really know all the risks?  The video suggests that the worst case would be an ineffective mutant, or mosquitoes that adapt too quickly.  How about an error in the gene splicing that creates another type of problem?  If dominant, it too would take over the population and perhaps spread some new problem world wide.  Keeping mosquito test subjects isolated is very difficult, so whatever we do, we must assume it will spread around the world.  And how might those mosquitos adapt? We need to be sure we have thoroughly considered all possibilities before proceding.

Not to piss in the punch-bowl, but what is the true long-term result of wiping out Malaria, Dengue and a host of other illnesses?
Aside from skyrocketing human population [people in Malaria zones tend to breed large families. They know that many kids might die, so they make more kids], the real risk is in longer human lifespans.
So, people live longer, and more of their kids live to adulthood.
What kind of pressure would that place on the current food/housing/medical care/political stability of the Planet to breed without limits?

Oh, the hidden 'cost' in all this is the Human immune system.
Some people have resistance to virus XYZ. They live longer, raise XYZ resistant kids.
People with no resistance to XYZ get sick and die. No passing on XYZ susceptible genes.
BUT....
If the vector for XYZ [mosquitoes, whatever] is eradicated, genetic 'filtering' is fully removed. Everyone lives, everyone breeds, no one has their resistance to XYZ 'challenged'.
This in essence 'short-circuits' natural selection, resulting in losing genetic diversity.

There are a pair of ethical prerogatives here. Firstly, that the ability to save human lives on a mass scale /should/ be done. If you have the ability to keep hundreds (in this case thousands upon thousands) of people from dying and do nothing, it is tantamount to having decided they'd no right to live.
Unfortunately, the second ethical prerogative is to not cause more harm by the saving of lives. We are still mostly uncertain how both the virus and the mosquito population will react to the gene editing, and while more testing would be fantastic, societal pressure will, as such, begin stressing that this be resolved sooner rather than later.
I am not okay with condemning so many people to death if a solution is available, but I also want to see that the solution is just that, and not a stopgap, or ultimately cause for more problems. I believe wholeheartedly that CRISPR and genetic modification can, should and will lead us to a better future, but a more cautious approach would not be remiss, as gene editing is in its infancy. This is not a simple question with a simple answer, and as much as I feel that if we can save lives now we should, there simply isn't enough aggregated data to be able to make a properly educated decision.

I actually agree with most things said in this video. Unfortunately the ultimate truth is that the technology is fairly recent, our understanding of how the genetic world works is changing on a day to day basis. . .well, maybe not that rapidly but we learn a massive amount about the human body as well as anti-bodies and well, everything in the world. This might seem like a 'good idea' but we have no idea how everything would react. What if the new genetic modifications we make have an adverse effect on not just the virus but another virus? We may test for a million viruses but what happens if one of the viruses we test for, like malaria changes and instead of eradicating a virus, we create a super virus that is resistant to modern medicine? The question here is not the issue but your outlook on life. Are you an optimist/humanitarian and believe it will all work out? Then of course we should use it. If you are a pessimist/realist, you should assume that despite the chances of something going wrong here, the chances that this might cause problems in this case or future cases, should be considered a real issue. As such, you should assume the worst and say that this is not something that we should do.
I personally am a pragmatist and I believe that the new technology is a wild card. We may understand what we are doing but we do not yet know the repercussions of our actions. There are plenty of other things that we should be railing and ranting against that have a far higher probability of creating dangerous circumstances towards humans (like the uncontrolled feeding of cows with antibiotics and growth hormones that some studies have linked to antibiotic resistant strains of dangerous pathogens) but that doesn't mean that we should be using something just because we figured out how. Also the word 'hope' when referring to the speed at which Plasmodium may adapt. If even a single mosquito ends up with a weakened immune system, for whatever reason, and it ends up perhaps in a pool filled with Plasmodium, it could take as little as a day before the Plasmodium could adapt using just a brute force approach. I do not know how well Plasmodium is at adapting but there have been studies that show antibiotics becoming increasingly weak over a very short period of time. As such, the chances that this is the silver bullet that will end all the suffering seems like a pie in the sky dream. So I think that this could work in the future, it may even work now however there is no rush. At the risk of sounding callous and uncaring, this has been a problem that has persisted for a long time and there is no rush to try and eliminate it before we are ready. If we create a stronger strain of Plasmodium, we may find that our efforts have only made it that much harder and that much further out of reach.
If they truly had some kind of end all understanding of the technology, they could just as easily engineer a genetic fault that would cause the species to become infertile after so many generations. Now I know there would ecological issues caused by the deaths of trillions of animals that are part of the aquatic and avian food chains and it would effect the entire worlds species after a time, but just as this would have massive repercussions we couldn't fully predict, the original plan contains the same risks.

They are releasing large quantities of males modified so that their offspring will self-destruct in their larval stage. Releasing them in waves and in sufficient quantities can crash a mosquito population very quickly. It's not as effective as adding an immunizing gene to the population (because the self-destruct gene obviously doesn't propagate) but doing this for long enough could wipe out mosquitoes in certain areas, and perhaps wipe them out altogether.
Many people will object against eradicating mosquitoes, even though most would not hesitate a second to eradicate the malaria parasite. The arguments would include them being a vital part of the ecosystem (are they?), playing a crucial role, yada yada yada.
The mosquito is a very successful parasite that serves as a natural transfer vector for other parasites. After we edit them for malaria, we'd have to edit them for dengue fever, then zika virus, and so on and so forth. Why not just get rid of them? We've killed off other species, mostly by not giving a shit, but sometimes on purpose. I'm all for conserving the nature (most of the time), but the mosquito is a vicious parasite. As I said, we wouldn't hesitate to eradicate the malaria parasite, or any of the deadly viruses they spread. Mosquito is a parasite just like them, just a little more complex one.

But isn't malaria a 3rd world disease? Why should we fund them? It's much better for us and for them that malaria exist. Had they been willing to educate themselves and spurt only 2-3 children, then we should consider.

I'm seeing a lot of comments advocating a test in a controlled environment to determine unforeseen consequences and minimise risk. Others saying there needs to be a big international discussion. There's some sense to both, but I'm doubtful either would work for 2 reasons.

1). Firstly, politically, there's no consequence for ignoring malaria. No politician is going to be impeached for inaction. But if the GEing does happen and it doesn't work perfectly, they're risking being as tied with it's failure as Oppenheimer would be to decades of nuclear brinksmanship. The media may give the GE'ed bugs a lasting nickname based on the politicians who tried hardest to save millions, and it WILL stick. So it's naive to think a discussion that amounts to "we need you to risk your careers for this stuff no large amount of activists have cared about for decades" is one that needs to happen quickly and will be taken urgently.

2). You can't build a lab with an ecosystem large enough, populated densely enough, modelled accurately enough and run to it for long enough test for all problems - one's that might only emerge decades later.

- To build it large enough, you have to build one too small, discover it's too small, and get approval build it bigger - assuming that it was too small won't be seen as such a failure it gets scrapped... And this may happen multiple times.

- There's no way to measure accuracy. How do you determine the exact number of mosquitoes to place in a given area? Doesn't accuracy demand sticking people in there with the malaria carrying mosquitoes(!)? How'd you ensure the monitoring systems needed to tell they're breeding or not aren't throwing off the results? What's an acceptable level of inaccuracy? If the experiment won't give a wholly meaningful answer, is still low enough to justify the costs of the controlled environment? Or the loss of life in delaying release them in the wild?

- Even if the above was managed, how do you know when enough generations of GE'ed mosquito have been breed to know for absolute certain there won't be unintended consequences down the line? Or conversely, if you do know, how do you convince people who don't believe you, and prevent a radicalised backlash? (think people bombing GE'ing labs because they don't agree with them the way that happens with abortion clinics)

The problem isn't simply "man, fuck politicians" or "just build the giant Wardian case, throw in the bugs and have the poindexters gawk at it until they figure out if its ready already".

The problem is we can't know what will happen and neither more discussion or prep will change that meaningfully.

I'm sure that at least a few people will disagree, but I think we should try and use this technology. It benefits us, because it will cut out malaria, and it benefits the mosquitoes, because they don't gain anything from being infected by the parasite. As long as we use this technology only to solve serious genetic problems, we're doing the right thing. I'm not saying that genetic modification is the way we should do everything. I don't think it should be used to create designer babies or weird hybrid species. However, in cases such as this, I think that there's nothing wrong with the idea and that we should at least try. CRISPR could save millions of lives if we use it the right way. Genetic modification is one of the inventions which, despite concerns, could well be the way of the future. I say research further before it is implemented. There is a TON that can go wrong, and if we aren't careful it may open floodgates that cause ultimately negative (or useless) gene editing that may widely damage ecosystems if let loose. However it may also open the floodgates for all new problems, such as making Killer Bees a useful strain of honeybee and maybe assure that, should Apis Mellifera suddenly go extinct, we have a quick and easy backup species that can take over. It could be also used to ultimately aid food sources in a way that can make people calm the hell down regarding growth hormones in our meat and milk and do so in a way that is both humane and profitable for both us and the ecosystem (e.g. if methane caused by agriculture due to the amount of food these guys produce helps cause global warming, why not edit their genes so that they pass less methane or convert it into a less volatile chemical? Or perhaps it can give us a be-all-end-all feed crop for grazing animals that can provide them with plenty of food and be healthier for them so that they don't pass as much gas?).

TL:DR - Everything in moderation. Let them develop the technology and do further testing for a couple more years. Yes, children may die to malaria, but they also die in wars, famine, and abuse, and using CRISP-R isn't going to magically end child suffering. It's like making a game; the longer they have to spend, test, and assure that nothing will go wrong, the less likely something will go horribly wrong on launch and ruin everyone's day...except instead of a video game it's a genetically edited mosquito strain, which can only end badly if it does go wrong.

There actually are a few precedents for this kind of genomics manipulation, albeit through a more crude method. Look up the "sterile insect technique". It's basically crude, randomized genetic manipulation through irradiation, resulting in sterility. We've already wiped out screw-worm fly populations with this method, and it's saved us billions in lost livestock. The ONLY reason we haven't done this before with mosquitoes is that it's expensive to individually irradiate and requires an insect with low male/female ratios.

But hey, you know what would be better than "slightly less horrible mosquitoes" or "completely extinct mosquitoes"? Mosquitoes that run on water, algae and chlorophyll that turn into an environmentally friendly liquid fuel at the end of their life cycle. That's your project for after you halt the aging process and cure cancer. Get to it, genetic engineers.

I mean holy smokes! People have no clue what a leap CRISPR is. Evolution is driven by changes to the genetic code: Random and induced mutation, horizontal gene transfer, sexual reproduction... Until now we have been like a dandelion blowing in the genetic wind. Suddenly we have become an eagle. We can actually direct the morphology of our bodies. We are so well accustomed to this ape shape, that all of our visions of advanced humans are some form of this ape shape. We are no longer restricted in this way. We can now ask ourselves: What is the most optimal body to inhabit on this planet as it exists today? this may not  be merely restricted to progeny, either... it may be quite possible to "live edit" our bodies. Imagine updating your genome, the same way you update your OS. Instead of working so hard to adapt to the hostile environment of a sub-terran climate on an alien planet, we can conform our bodies to find the conditions favorable (within parameters, of course). These are now realistic theoretical possibilities! Craze balls! I would guess that in less than 1000 years there will be a tremendously diverse array of "human" body variations that will be radically different (unrecognizable) from the one we all share today.

Here's the thing: We are very likely to f*** it up eventually. As a species, we don't seem to be all that good on long-term vigilance. The remaining question then becomes, "Will there be anyone left with the will and the resources to patch it up afterwords?" And that depends on how bad the error will be, so who knows.

Eradicate Malaria? Yeah, sure. Sounds pretty-much like a no-brainer to me, but it's not the real question. The real question is whether or not we, as a species, are ready to embrace / deploy yet another technology that, if not very carefully managed (forever), could make the planet un-inhabitable for humans.

(Is there anyway we could do it, just this once, and not tell anyone? S'pose not.)

I think the question is moot. We can, therefore we will. It'll be yet another burden for the grown-ups among us to shoulder. Let's hope we're up to it. (Quoting John Lithgow from "The Manhattan Project", "I bet we make it. Any takers?")

And so you've informed me of yet another type of self-annihilation for our species that I might loose sleep over. O.K. Thanks. Knowing it gives us our first (and perhaps only) chance of preventing it.

To those that would say that the use of CRISPR constitutes as 'playing God' - a translation of often-repeated comments posted in the indecipherable language of Troll to English:

A good question to ask here would be to wonder at which point we are playing God. I am not a religious person myself, I will admit that, but if God has created this universe, all of its laws and all that is in it; then by altering the genetic makeup of our own and other species, isn't that just one part of the universe interacting with another, within the laws we cannot break?
I am not the most well-versed in Biblical Literature, but I recall hearing that God gave the people free will. Are we not allowed to exercise this free will that was bestowed upon us by Him personally, and would it not be an insult to presume to know when we are or are not allowed to use it?
If humans are inherently imperfect, then not one of us is capable of knowing what constitutes 'playing God'. Wouldn't breaking the laws of physics (not as we know them, but as they are), like creating matter out of nothing be closer to 'playing God'? Because that is the only thing that I can think of that is literally impossible within the laws of this universe; the laws that God made.

In Thomas Malthus' work, An Essay on the Principle of Population as it affects the Future Improvement of Society, he raises the point that humanity will always outrun it's ability to feed itself. Without control such as war, famine and disease humanity could multiply geometrically. So for example if the population were 1 billion it could potentially multiply to 256 billion within 200 years without regulation. This video asks the question is it ethical to not use this technology when 1000 children die a day? I ask back, is it ethical to strive for the goal of completely eliminating these regulatory factors when the worlds population is already growing exponentially? If there was an epidemic in which the human population was rapidly plummeting, I would of course have a different view. Specific populations of humans through evolution have already developed genetic resistance to malaria, and I believe if that occurs naturally then so be it. But there are times when we should not intervene.

Crispr, if implemented on a large enough scale would cause a medical revolution on the grandest of scales. Tens of millions, hell, hundreds of millions of lives saved by changing something we can hardly see. We take risks everyday but if the benefits outweigh the risk then we continue our lives. I believe that this is worth the risk.

My greatest concern is that this would create a selective force that would backfire in some way.

It's an absolutely a genius plan, and I am leaning toward the "do it" side. But as much as the image of child corpses horrifies me, the idea that we could be unleashing something even more dangerous than nuclear weapons is even more horrifying.

We need more research into how gene drives affect populations, specifically how it alters the dynamics of natural selection on both the host animal and the parasite. It would be foolhardy to proceed until we have good reason to believe it would work in our favor. I'm talking about at least three to one odds that nothing "bad" will happen.

We also need to consider how we regulate the use of such a technology, as it could conceivably be used in other animals. I know it would take thousands of generations to fully come into effect. But if you have goals such as "wipe out the brown people" and you're intelligent enough to do this...then you could easily be patient enough to drop such a genetic bomb knowing that you won't live to see it's effects...but that they WILL happen.

Not to mention again that we have no idea how the drives would fare in the long run. What if the parasite DOES confer an advantage to the mosquito population and we just don't know what it is? We could destroy a vital part of an ecosystem by accident...again. And there'd be no fixing it this time.

Again, I'm leaning towards supporting the idea...it's just that I really don't want to see us do something stupid out of a desire to help.

TO THE PEOPLE WHO THINK WE ARE CREATING A NEW SPECIES OR WHO DON'T UNDERSTAND SPECIATION
Not being able to produce offspring is a matter of having a different number of chromosomes. For example, if a chimp (24 chromosomes in its haploid gonadal cell) mixed with a human (23 chromosomes in its haploid gonadal cell), we have an infertile offspring. Naturally, the 2 species have to be very similar so that the individual single chromosomes that pair up correspond to code for the same things or very similar. This is incompatible when you cross homologous structures since they are genetically very distinct. Really this is all you need to give birth to an infertile offspring.

Fun Fact: we have a common ancestor with Drosophila melanogaster (fruit fly). Other than the difference between the ventral CNS (central nervous system) compared to our dorsal CNS, they are and work identically, proving a common ancestor. :)
Not too shaby... not too flattering hahaha

Source: Held Jr, L. I. (2009). Quirks of human anatomy: an evo-devo look at the human body. Cambridge University Press.

It's not difficult to imagine that this may not be effective, that the malaria parasite can evolve the same way that bacteria defeat our antibiotics. The protein that is the engineered mosquito is programmed to attack can change, rendering it ineffective. Furthermore, the gene that is inserted to ensure that the anti-malaria gene is propagated preferentially can be subsequently duplicated and mutated in a way that might give preference to, say, breeding or defense against predators. I'm just pulling ideas off the top of my head - I'm sure there are many, many other ways that unintended consequences can creep into the system.

Personally, I feel that a more nuanced and long-term solution is needed. We shouldn't treat mosquitoes like we treat antibiotics - as an incremental change that would need to be repeated every time something mutates. Let's think bigger - why not breed a mosquito variant that benefits metabolically from consuming malaria organisms? That way, there is an evolutionary advantage for mosquitoes that consume malaria, thus creating a self-perpetuating population of malaria-eating mosquitoes. Furthermore, a failsafe is also needed to ensure that the gene doesn't change into something we don't want. For example, we encode a toxin into the gene that is neutralized only when in tandem with the gene drive. If either gene mutates or is copied elsewhere, the organism dies.

Mosquitoes are already free to mutate naturally, and mutations can be dominant naturally. The natural mutations might be harmful, neutral, or beneficial to the mosquito but harmful mutations don't survive. Since there is already a natural risk that a mutant mosquito could be harmful to the planet, I don't see an increased risk by introducing a neutral mutation from the mosquito's point of view that is beneficial to humans. Less infant mortality ultimately leads to a more healthy human population that is more satisfied with life, with less poverty.

It's really cool because I actually met the scientist that's working on this. It was amazing seeing the lab where they nurture and modify all these mosquitoes. But that's what the video's about, so I would like to point out several important things you missed.

First is that you imply we can do this immediately, and believe me, we would if if we could. It's not really an ethical dilemma, rather, a predicament with how to make these mosquitoes to begin with. So, in engineering these mosquitoes, Ellena (the scientist) has run into 2 major problems:
The first is that there are many, many species of mosquitoes. You have to fix the code in each of them, not just a few. Each of those species slightly evolves every year too, so they need new samples annually.
The second issue is that these aren't real mosquitoes. They are "lab grown" mosquitoes so they are unable to breed with real mosquitoes. To make things worse, the process used to inject the genetic code kills all of the bacteria in the mosquitoes. These bacteria are fundamental for its survival and reproduction.
There are probably some other issues but I forgot. But what I'm trying to say is it's really not as simple as you make it out to be. We aren't there yet, we still have some advances to make first ;)

Couldn't they KRISPER a gene to make all offspring of mosquitoes Male? The males would spend their time and energy, flying around, seeking out females to breed with, which would create more anti-mosquito warriors. If enough were released in enough areas, it should cut the population way down or possibly wipe them out completely. I can't think of a more practical way. As a fail-safe, you could also add in the gene change for parasite immunity, in case females are somehow created.

The reason I believe this is the perfect and only solution, is because in the past, I thought, if you could make them genetically mutated so that they can't survive long enough to breed, but the problem with that approach, is that it only works on 1 generation, even if the initial male mosquitoes all mated with many of them. The area where they were released may exterminate all of them, but new mosquitoes would migrate there and re-populate the area. Therefore, a method of weakening mosquitoes, would require humans to constantly be re-creating these inferior mosquitoes which would waste tons of time and money. The benefit, is that it would remain in the control of humans, where they can easily abort the project, but that also means it would be a never ending war that can't be won, basically just for the purpose of profiting the people who are employed to create these mosquitoes.

Also, while we eliminate mosquitoes, lets consider eliminating LoveBugs.

Genetics are quite unpredictable... and CRISPR especially. What was the percentage of unexpected mutation, again? I don't think it was as high as 35%, but that's the number that comes to mind presently. At that rate, there is a VERY GOOD chance that the mosquitoes could receive a mutation that makes them vulnerable to FAR more diseases, possibly increasing the deathtoll.

Imagine if something like Ebola or AIDs diseases became transmittable. Both are incurable, the former leads to death more than half the time in a short time span, and the latter already kills more people than the Holocaust every few years without mosquitoes bringing it into the general public (it also tends to pass on to your kids).

We're getting all excited that we're working with a rock now, instead of our bare hands. But this is a rock, not a scalpel. Putting billions of people in your cross-hairs to save millions is not moral, it's reckless.

Atfer having studied population-based genetics at university (a weird kind of science which leads us to predict how a population -and not just an individual - would genetically evolve over generations given specific circumstances) I'm not that sure if that transgenic modification would eventually spread around the whole mosquitoe population by just being dominant over the silvester copy already existent in there.

Let's be less technical: in our specie having brown eyes is dominant over the rest of the alternatives, and that has been that way since the gen started to get around with us so, why haven't we all brown eyes? I mean, there was plenty of time to that to happen if being dominant was the only meaningful prerequisite existant. This is because of evolution: there is something called biological efficency which happens to matematically determine the efectiveness of a specific gen on a specific environment by taking into account the natural selection which will always be there. Briefly summarised this means that a gen would only spread if it actually gives an extra advantage to the individuals carrying it over the guys who doesn't by, for example, making them more attractive to females or whatever. The opposite thing would happen if the gen was disadvantageous for those indiviuals carrying it: it would eventually disappear.

So the real question here is: does the mutation bring on a good enough advantage to the transgenic mosquitoes over the silvester ones to justify that massive spread we are expecting from it? Mosquitoes don't gain anything from those malaria parasites as it's said in the video but they don't lose too much neither as malaria doesn't make them sick: it wants them alive spreading the illness over their real prey, they're just a vehicle - a pretty effective one. Given the extreme situation that the mutation doesn't change at all the efectiveness of the mosquitoes (also technically called a neutral mutation) then the gen wouldn't spread neither as the number of copies of it would just stabilize over the whole population after one generation. For those interested in this fact I highly recommend you to look into Hardy-Weinberg equilibriums.

To sum up there is just one way of making those useful mosquitoes predominate over its silvester relatives: we need them to be better than the already existant ones. if not, we're just going to waste money into a secured failure. The better they are compared to the other ones, the faster they will spread.

Alternatively, we have also postulated a method using genetically modified mosquitoes to completely eradicate mosquitoes, and while that may sound bad, it isn't really.  We would eradicate all of the diseases transmitted by a given species of mosquitoes in one go, and they would have no chance to adapt whatsoever.  There is some debate as to whether or not mosquitoes are vital to any ecosystems, but there is very little evidence that they actually are, as most things that eat mosquitoes eat other insects as well, meaning they would be able to survive without them.

On the other hand though, considering the concept of a Malthusianism (when populations increase faster than their needed resources, the populace needs to be "checked" and decreased via some kind of disaster)... maybe it's not such a good idea.

Does Malaria exist as a way to keep our huge population in check? What would happen to the world's scarce resources when the people who are currently dying of Malaria/Dengue/Zika etc are alive and contribute to the draining of resources?

Lastly, if we do end up modifying mosquitoes successfully, is that the first step in humanity "playing god?" Or have we already been doing that since vaccines and medicine came into being?

To be perfectly honest, the issue I have with this is the issue I have with GMO's; namely, far too little research has been done into the actual short and long term effects of this DNA editing. We do not understand the programming language of living organisms nearly enough as we should to be able to make assumptions this early, and it is very easy for this to have unpredictable cascade effects if we do it without thought. I once had a crazy idea after waking up from a vivid dream: what if we genetically engineered a species-specific disease that only harms mosquitoes, but can be carried by humans in their blood? If I remember correctly about species interactions with diseases, I think there are diseases that are merely carried by one species but affect another.

(Isn't that the case with modern mosquitoes and malaria? I often wonder if mosquitoes are naturally immune to the harmful, cell-altering effects of the malaria parasites they carry. If you are a science expert, please shed some light on this for me, thanks.)

My idea of an anti-mosquito virus carried by humans would only affect human-populated areas that coexist with mosquito populations. So in a forest in the middle of nowhere, mosquitoes would be relatively unaffected. Going with the assumption that this virus works, it would not possibly cause mosquito extinction (especially with this video's point that they reproduce so fast and have existed for a very long time on Earth, so their extinction would be extremely far-fetched). In short, the virus would be very reactive, rather than proactive in the war against mosquitoes. The idea is that as soon as mosquitoes bite humans, they would get infected with a virus that is only lethal to them. If they don't bite humans carrying this virus, then they would be fine.

I honestly think we should do it. These diseases kill so many, and now that Crisper exists, that technology is going to be used sooner or later on something. I would rather it's first 'public run' be something that benefits everyone around the world, like stopping mosquito populations from carrying lethal diseases, rather than using it on humans to edit out faults in our genes. It will get there soon enough, I am sure, but a large-scale 'test' as it were SHOULD be conducted to see how the Crisper edits hold up over generations, and a fast-breeding species like Mosquitoes could give us our first hints on what might go right or wrong. Obviously it's not going to yield a LOT of valuable data, seeing as we are very different from mosquitoes, but it will give us our first hints on what happens with edited genes once they're released into the wild. Questions like, are the edited genes more vulnerable to mutation? Did editing in the gene negatively interact with any of the other existing genes in the mosquito? Did mosquitoes with the edited gene have any impact on the animals who eat them? Doing this could do a LOT of good, both in the name of curing disease and in the name of research itself, and lay a lot of fears to rest.

The first problem that came to my mind is that 88% of the infected population is in Africa (http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs094/en/), a place that has rampant overpopulation even with the highest mortality index in the world. Erradicating Malaria would skyrocket the population to inimaginable levels, and there are enough people there already competing for the same resources, given that Africa has also the lowest food production per capita in the world. I think Project Needlenose needs to be preceded and accompanied by a campaign for sexual education, contraceptive methods and agriculture (arable land in Africa is way underused), which already exist but its efforts should be doubled.

All that people that blame (maybe even rightfully so) European countries for the state of Africa today, should be pushing these types of campaigns to the betterment of the living conditions in Africa rather than pressuring their government to importem them over to Europe.

We could craft a closed ecosystem similar to the habitat these mosquitos live in, perhaps indoors in a large scientific facility designed so that the possibility of any organic material leaving is completely mitigated, then we could observe the effects on a relatively large scale over a long period of time. Because, considering this type of project has never been done before, there are bound to be mounds of unforeseen consequences, both positive and negative. Obviously this would take a tremendous amount of manpower and funding, but like the video suggests, we can't really afford to screw this up. In my opinion, there is absolutely nothing ethically wrong with the use of CRISPR for this sort of thing, as long as we test in thoughtful experiments over and over again, to determine what possible outcomes we could face. Of course if, in our safe, closed experiments, we find this leads to super intelligent dog-sized mosquitos that are crammed full of several newly evolved superviruses, we should certainly revaluate some things, but if it works as intended, then really the only problem we'll eventually be worsening is population control... but with the rate technology is constantly accelerating, we might be able to expand colonies to the Moon or Mars in enough time to counteract the overpopulation. Hopefully... :p

I believe than whatever the solution, at some points humans would want to stop the death-madness caused by those diseases. Between genetic mutation of the hosts or complete eradication of a species (in this case mosquitoes), for me the 1st solution is better. Yes sure, maybe we will come-up with a great treatment or even vaccine but if we judge with only the solutions we have at hands, I'm fine with making mosquitoes resistant to malaria. Maybe we can test it for a smaller disease/population and monitor the outcome for a few years. Mosquitoes being fast reproducers, we could see rapidly what kind of additional mutations it could cause on them. If there is none and we can avoid creating the next Godzilla-mosquito, let's just do it case by case.

Another discussion in the scientist community is a way to cripple female mosquitoes through an altered gene. Male mosquitoes are unaffected by this gene while female mosquitoes develop defective wings, which make them unable to survive. The male mosquitoes are able to fly and spread the gene via mating to the next generation. This would lead to a massive decrease of the mosquito population. One of the reasons why this isn't used yet is that it is unsure which impact mosquitoes have on the food chain and if a massively decreased population would lead to other massive decreases/increases of other animal populations.

Yes, we should. It's been tried on limited scales, albeit with genes that wipe out mosquitoes rather than wipe out malaria. This poses the least potential ecological danger (ecologies are complicated and extinctions sometimes have knock on effects that can't be predicted), while retaining all the good it would do (no malaria). However, the precise method to do so needs to be, well, done right. We need to ensure that any anti-malarial drugs we have currently won't be less effective should malaria adapt. That may take longer, but would hopefully ensure that should malaria not be wiped out completely, that we would still be able to treat it.

I find it positive that we're at least discussing the pros and cons now with such a open and shut gene-mod case such as this one regarding malaria, because that means we'll exercise even more caution in gene-mod cases that have less clear pros and worse possible cons.

I think we should use technology and innovation with care. We don't want unintended consequences, but we can solve some of humanity's biggest problems through new concepts and tech. I agree we should, but we need to be able to think both ethically and responsibly.
