If I'm not mistaken, mosquitoes are parasites as well, yes? Eventually it would be preferable to completely eliminate them along with fleas and ticks, as they contribute nothing or less than nothing to an ecosystem.

I can't remember if this was something I read about or one of my musings, but a potential way to eliminate mosquitoes is to use gene therapy to turn reproductive cycles on its head. This can be done efficiently with this new Gene Drive, like this:

A batch of edited male mosquitoes are released into the wild. They are edited by having genetic material that either a) kills or sterilises female offspring, or in the case of the Gene Drive b) edits out an entire half-a-chromosome turning ALL offspring male (or 99.5% as they say). The result of it is a vast overpopulation of male mosquitoes that keep seeking out females, eventually driving the species, and all viruses borne with it, extinct.

THERE IS A BIG HOWEVER THOUGH. Genetics, from what I can gather, are more fluid than first appearances. Viruses make small modifications to genes every year (as seen with Zika), and there is speculation that the course of evolution sometimes leads to genetic material from other species being used in the natural process. So what happens if Gene Drive data becomes absorbed into a human system?

To this, there is no definitive answer for obvious reasons. Which is why it's important to start small-scale with tiny levels of genetic material. Potentially the best option would be to add a very small "precursor" edit into a species and see what happens in the wild. It may be that the malaria block is small enough, but I don't know how large this edited data is actually meant to be. From there, we can ramp up more aggressive tests, but only if results and risks are being closely observed.

This is just my thoughts and understandings. Tell me yours.
I eagerly anticipate not just genetically modified animals, but designer babies as well.

For the sake of discussion: population growth.
The human population has been growing at an incredible rate precisely because people are surviving better and longer. This has had both good and bad consequences. However, humans - like every species - are only suppose to thrive in niches, and making the entire planet our niche is straining naturally available resources to the point of an uncertain future. Death is depressing, but it's also necessary in a closed eco-system. Nature has been using malaria as a way to balance population growth, and so quickly eradicating it could cause a huge population boom that humanity is not yet capable of supporting.

Yeah, I think it's a bad idea. It working as intended might actually be the worst case scenario. Think of any other time we decided to eradicate a predator - its former prey grew drastically in numbers. The deaths in children would drop at first, but who can say they won't grow back to even higher numbers from all the deaths by starvation caused by a sudden growth in population?

Personally, I don't really understand why people have an issue with human manipulation of genes when we have been doing it for years with animals with less humane ways. With CRISPR, we could manipulate genes in a way that is more logical and practical such as wiping out malaria as opposed to just physical appearance. The only problem is not that Malaria might mutate and get worse. We hardly think about ecosystems when we come to discuss this matter. The solution presented in this video sounds better than the one suggested by some scientists saying that mosquitoes should be eradicated. The ecology and biomass of mosquitoes make them crucial parts of ecosystems. However, if we drastically change the population dynamics of mosquitoes what happens? I guess mosquitoes get affected by malaria as well (this is also a parasite of the mosquitoes), what are the consequences if malaria disappears? Furthermore, not only humans are affected by animals. What will happen in the population dynamics of other animals changes?

Parasites are key species of ecosystems, the equilibrium of many ecosystems depends of their abundance. Remove this elements and the consequences might be huge and unexpected. I am far to say that malaria should not be fought as hard as possible, only that we should seriously consider these issues...

I don't think that it is a good idea to interfere with nature. What if a new version of the disease popped up? It could have a super-immune system that can't be matched by our limited medicine. A new wave of illnesses could break out in the scale of the Plague in Europe. I am not saying that the people suffering and dying from the disease are expendable, I just think that we should help them in another way. There should be better medical care in poor and rural areas, so the risk of becoming infected or dying is greatly reduced. Well-off nations should spend their extra money on helping those in need instead of trying to rival each other.

Here's an interesting thing we discussed at our genetics class this week:
Let's say we engineer a cell that is capable of taking any role we choose(be it a muscle cell or a neuron, etc.). We program this cell to be able to work without food for X amount of time. After that amount of time passes, the cell duplicates, with the original dying, as the new one takes it's place.
Would we still need to feed these cells, and if not, couldn't this make it so we have an infinite amount of working cells, basically giving us unlimited energy for whatever task they're programmed to do?

So given the state of the planet, we need malaria, zika, HIV, cancer, and heart disease to control the population. OR eradicate malaria but put a 1 child limit on the entire world. They should definitely try to test it out on a few small, enclosed populations, before releasing modified mosquitoes into the wild. If malaria is wiped out to quickly to adapt in all of, say, two dozen or so tests, then it would probably be safe to introduce the Newsquitoes into an isolated population, and see how it goes. If no isolated, malaria-carrying populations exist, then it would probably be better to perform another few large scale tests, with larger contained populations. Only if all goes well, and we can insure the chances of super-malaria are infinitesimally small, would I release the Newsquitoes into the general population. There should also be backups in place, just in case, further measures, like.... I don't know, mosquitoes that quickly die when infected with malaria. That would be a less effective solution than killing off the parasite itself, but would at least serve as a failsafe to reduce the spread of malaria in the event that it manages to adapt to the antibodies.

Don't see much of this in the comments, so I'm gonna try and have a discussion about this. Personally, I'm still undecided on whether this should be done or not. What you're doing is eliminating a parasite without causing harm to mosquitoes themselves, So the eco system wont get messed up too much. But for all we know this could go horribly wrong, what if the parasite adapts? What if it becomes resistant? Then we've just wasted a whole lot of time and money for nothing. And also, if we are successful in eradicating malaria everybody and their mother will want to do this to all kinds of diseases. Now lets say I want to eliminate another parasite, but I want to do it quick, so I rush it. I don't look at everything and basically hope that nothing goes wrong. But I have horrible luck and it was all a waste and the parasite I was trying to eliminate becomes a lot stronger. Like I said before I have horrible luck so maybe the parasite becomes so strong it becomes incurable. Then what happens (obviously this example is an extreme). What I'm trying to say is even if we get it right with malaria, doesn't mean we wont get it right with others, and if we get it right once it will it will cause everyone to experiment with this. A way to fix the problem of "rushing it" could be strict government policy (but that again doesn't stop illeagal activities." Also if things like this consistently work, and we are successful in destroying many forms of diseases, the problem of over-population comes up. Which brings up a whole new argument.
